The '''2011 Alexandria bombing''' was an attack on [[Copts|Coptic Christians]] in Alexandria, Egypt, on Saturday, 1 January 2011. Twenty three people died as a result of the attack, all of them Coptic Christians.<ref name="reuters"/><ref name="Yom7">{{Cite news|title=Ø£Ø³Ù Ø§Ø¡ Ø¶Ø­Ø§ÙØ§ ÙÙ ØµØ§Ø¨Ù Ø­Ø§Ø¯Ø« Ø§ÙÙØ¬Ø§Ø± Ø§ÙØ¥Ø³ÙÙØ¯Ø±ÙØ©|url=http://www.youm7.com/News.asp?NewsID=328202|accessdate=2 January 2011|newspaper=El Yom El Sabe|date=2 January 2011}}</ref> Some 97 more people were injured.<ref name="bbc">{{Cite news|title=Egypt bomb kills 21 at Alexandria Coptic church|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12101748|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=BBC News |date=1 January 2011}}</ref> This was the deadliest act of violence against Egypt's Christian minority in a decade, since the [[Kosheh massacre]] in 2000 left 21 Copts dead.<ref name="NY Times">{{Cite news|title=Fatal Bomb Hits a Church in Egypt |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=3&hp|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1 January 2011}}</ref>
== Background == {{Modern persecution of Coptic Christians}} Copts in Egypt complain of increasing persecution, including attacks by Muslim extremists and what they see as official discrimination by the state. Copts celebrate Christmas on 7 January. This was the second consecutive Christmas with violence. On Christmas Eve in 2010, a Muslim gunman fired on worshipers leaving a church in Upper Egypt, killing 7 people and wounding 10 others.<ref name="Fahim 2011-01-07">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/08/nyregion/08coptic.html?partner=rss&emc=rss |title=Sorrow in Brooklyn for Terror in Egypt|work=The New York Times |last=Fahim|first=Kareem|page=A16|date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref>
In the months prior to the incident, the religious ambiance in Egypt had been clouded by anti-Church sentiment, in particular regarding the public allegation made by [[Mohammad Salim Al-Awa]] that the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]] was storing weapons in churches and monasteries.<ref name="Awa">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/65471152-9030-4350-9448-79714469B785.htm |title=Ø§ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± â Ø¹Ø±Ø¨Ù â Ù Ø­Ø§Ù ÙÙ Ù ØµØ±ÙÙÙ ÙØªØ¶Ø§Ù ÙÙÙ Ù Ø¹ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§ |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=15 September 2010 |accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="ysaleh"/><ref name="CNN"/>
In November, a group calling itself Al-Qaeda in Iraq announced that all Christians in the Middle East would be "legitimate targets."<ref name="CNN" /> The Alexandria bombing occurred almost two months to the day after the [[2010 Baghdad church attack|attack on Our Lady of Salvation church]] in central Baghdad in what militants called a response to the mistreatment of Muslim converts by Egyptian Copts.<ref name="ysaleh" /> Al-Qaeda's Iraqi affiliate claimed responsibility for that attack and made new threats against Christians. The group threatened to attack Egyptian Copts if their church did not free two Christians, it said had been "imprisoned in their monasteries" for having converted to Islam. The two women were [[Kamilia Shehata|Camilia Chehata]] and Wafa Constantine, the wives of Coptic priests whose claimed conversion caused a stir in Egypt.<ref name=jazeera>{{Cite news|title=Deadly blast outside Egypt church|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111111533958901.html|accessdate=27 Jan 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=1 Jan 2011}}</ref>
Two weeks before the bombing an [[Islamism|Islamist]] website called for attacks on a list of Egypt's churches, and included the church that was hit.<ref name="ysaleh">{{Cite news |title= Suspected suicide bomber kills 17 at Egypt church.|author=Saleh, Yasmine |url= http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20110101/wl_nm/us_egypt_church_blast|newspaper=Yahoo News|date= 1 January 2011 |accessdate=2 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="longwar">[http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2011/01/suspected_suicide_bo.php "Suspected suicide bomber kills 21 in attack on Egyptian church"]. By BILL ROGGIO. 1 January 2011</ref>
== Bombing == An explosive device detonated in front of the Coptic Orthodox church of [[Saint Mark]] and [[Pope Peter of Alexandria|Pope Peter]] in the Sidi Bishr neighbourhood in Alexandria.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="CNN">{{Cite news|title=Explosion kills at least 21 at Egyptian church|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/01/egypt.attack/index.html?iref=NS1|accessdate=1 January 2011|publisher=CNN|date=1 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="longwar"/> Initial reports stated that it was a car explosion, however an Interior Ministry statement later declared that it was a [[suicide attack]], through the Egyptian official news agency.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="CNN"/><ref name="Guardian">{{Cite news|last=Batty|first=David|title=Egypt bomb kills new year churchgoers|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/01/egypt-bomb-kills-new-year-churchgoers|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="India News">{{cite web|url=http://news.indiavoice.info/news/suicide-bomber-kills-21-in-egypt-2011010120146 |title=Suicide bomber kills 21 in Egypt |publisher=IndiaVoice |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="CNN2">{{Cite news|title=Interior ministry: Suicide bomber behind Egypt church blast|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/01/egypt.attack/index.html?hpt=T2|accessdate=1 January 2011|publisher=CNN|date=1 January 2011}}</ref>
At the time of the blast, several thousand Coptic Christians were attending midnight prayer service at the church at the occasion of the new year.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="longwar"/> The explosion resulted in scattered body parts, destroyed cars and smashed windows.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="ysaleh"/> 21 Coptic Christians were killed immediately following the explosion, or soon after, and about 97 people â most of them Christians â were injured.<ref name="masrawy"/><ref name="bbc"/><ref name="CNN"/><ref name="longwar"/> The remains were covered with newspapers until they were brought inside the church. Two more Copts died in the hospital over the few days following the attack, raising the total number to 23, all of whom were Coptic Christians.<ref name="reuters"/>
Forensic testing confirmed that the explosive device used was homemade and contained nails and ball-bearings.<ref name="CNN2"/> The Interior Ministry stated that the bomb was filled with small pieces of metal to serve as [[Fragmentation (weaponry)|shrapnel]],<ref name="Kristen Chick">{{Cite news | last= Chick | first= Kristen | url= http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0101/Egypt-church-bombing-Why-some-point-to-Al-Qaeda-linked-group | title= Egypt church bombing: Why some point to Al Qaeda-linked group | work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] | date= 1 January 2011 }}</ref> and that a foreign-backed suicide bomber may have been responsible.<ref name="Kristen Chick" />
== Responsibility == Egypt's former Interior minister [[Habib Ibrahim El Adly]] said on 23 January that evidence proved that the Gaza-based ''Army of Islam'' planned and executed the attack. The group quickly denied the charge, while also reportedly expressing support for the bombing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt blames Gaza group for bombing|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112311414915283.html|accessdate=26 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Army of Islam denies responsibility for Egyptian church bombing|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-01/23/c_13703737.htm|accessdate=8 February 2011|newspaper=Xinhuanet|date=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Attorney General bans publication of Alex church attack findings|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/attorney-general-bans-publication-alex-church-attack-findings|accessdate=8 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al-youm|date=24 January 2011}}</ref> In July 2011 however, nobody had yet been brought to trial and the Coptic Church threatened to sue interior ministry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coptic Church threatens to sue interior ministry over Alexandria church bombing |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/480165|newspaper=Al Masry Al-youm|date=25 July 2011}}</ref>
== Reactions == === Coptic community in Egypt === Copts were deeply aggrieved by this attack, many believing that the Egyptian state security's failure to deal firmly with past attacks on Christians in Egypt contributed to this attack, while others went as far as to directly blame the State Security for the bombings.<ref name="Clashes Grow"/> One member of the Coptic community declared, "The government is the reason this happened. They are the terrorists who attack us every day."<ref name="Clashes Grow"/>
Following the bombing, several thousand Copts took to the streets in protest.<ref name="bbc"/> Furious Christians clashed with Egyptian police and Egyptian security forces.<ref name="bbc"/><ref>[http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/01/deadly-church-blast-sparks-christian-rage-in-egypt/ "Deadly church blast sparks Christian rage in Egypt"]. Euronews, 1 January 2011</ref> Christians and Muslims pelted each other with rocks, and cars were torched.<ref name="ysaleh"/> After these overnight protests, more than 100 Christians protested the following morning near the church that was attacked, chanting "We sacrifice our souls and blood for the [[Christian cross|Holy Cross]]" and "O Mubarak, the heart of the [[Copts]] is on fire".<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="ysaleh"/> The Egyptian police reacted by firing rubber bullets and tear gas at the Christians.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="NY Times"/>
In [[Cairo]], about 4,000 Christians and Muslims demonstrated against terrorism in the predominantly Christian neighborhood of [[Shubra]].<ref name="Elaph2">{{Cite news|title=Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ø© Ø¢ÙØ§Ù Ù ØµØ±Ù ØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙØ§ Ø¶Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ¥Ø±ÙØ§Ø¨ ÙÙ" Ø´Ø¨Ø±Ø§"|url=http://www.elaph.com/Web/news/2011/1/622220.html|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=Elaph|date=1 January 2011}} (in Arabic)</ref> The demonstration lasted for six hours and was joined by both government and opposition members of the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] and a number of political figures, including a former minister and [[Tomorrow Party]] leader [[Ayman Nour]]. In the same neighborhood of [[Shubra]], thousands of Coptic Christians clashed with riot police for three consecutive days, resulting in injuries to both Coptic civilians and riot police soldiers.<ref name="Clashes Grow">{{Cite news | last= Slackman | first= Michael | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/04/world/middleeast/04egypt.html | title= Clashes Grow as Egyptians Remain Angry After an Attack |work=New York Times | date= 4 Jan 2011 }}</ref>
Thousands of Copts demonstrated at the Monastery of [[Simon the Tanner|Saint Simon the Tanner]] in [[Cairo]]. The demonstrators called for the resignation of the Egyptian government. They chanted, "With our souls and blood we redeem our [[Christian cross|Cross]]". They then clashed with the Egyptian security forces, resulting in injuries to 12 of the Coptic demonstrators.<ref name="Asia One"/><ref name="The Australian"/>
In addition, thousands of Coptic Christians demonstrated outside the Egyptian ministry of foreign affairs and the state television buildings for two consecutive days.<ref name="Asia One"/><ref name="The Australian"/>
[[Pope Shenouda III]] strongly condemned the "criminal assault", blaming it on "forces that wish no good for Egypt".<ref name="Elaph1"/> The Pope also called upon the government to "speedily arrest and prosecute the perpetrator of this criminal act."<ref name="Elaph1"/> His personal secretary said the incident had "severely grieved us, because it is very alien to the love and harmony in which the nation lives".<ref name="Ashraf Sadiq">{{Cite news | last= Sadiq | first= Ashraf | url= http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/2983/Egypt/Politics-/Despite-attack,-Pope-Shenouda-will-preside-over-Ch.aspx | title= Despite attack, Pope Shenouda will preside over Christmas Mass in Abbaseya cathedral | publisher=ahramOnline | date= 1 Jan 2011 }}</ref>
The top cleric in Alexandria, the [[Vicar|Patriarchal Vicar]] [[Hegumen]] Ruweis Marcos, said that the Egyptian government and security forces wanted to blame the bombing on a suicide bomber instead of a car bomb in order to write off the crime as something carried out by a lone attacker.<ref name="bbc"/> He also denounced the lack of protection in front of the church, stating he was surprised to find only three soldiers and one officer guarding the church at such a sensitive time in spite of the recent numerous threats against Copts.<ref name="bbc"/>
The Synod of priests in Alexandria unanimously criticized the lax attitude of the Egyptian authorities towards the public expression of hatred against Coptic Christians.<ref name="ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨"/> In a statement issued by the Synod, the priests said that the attack on the church was "the result of anti-Christian mobilization and the lies recently propagated against the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]]."<ref name="ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨"/>
On the Sunday following the bombings, Coptic parishioners at the bombed church of Saint Mark and Pope Peter expressed anger, and protested discrimination that Christians in Egypt are facing.<ref name="ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨">{{Cite news | url= http://www.elaph.com/Web/news/2011/1/622368.html?entry=homepagemainmiddle | title= ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨ ÙÙ ÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø§ÙÙØ¯ÙØ³ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ§Ø³ÙÙØ¯Ø±ÙØ© | publisher=ahramOnline | date= 2 Jan 2011 | accessdate=2 Jan 2011}}</ref> One of the parishioners declared "in this country, we cannot even pray in churches." Another blamed the anti-Coptic sentiments spread by the Islamic mosques. The priest of the church blamed "Islamic fanaticism" and "Islamic extremism".<ref name="ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨"/> He called upon the Egyptian government to ensure the rights of the Christians in "life, prayer and work".<ref name="ÙØ¯Ø§Ø³ Ø§Ø­Ø¯ Ø­Ø²ÙÙ ÙØºØ§Ø¶Ø¨"/>
Officials of the [[Coptic Orthodox Church]] announced that prayers for Eastern Christmas would still be held, but that celebrations would be canceled.<ref name="Clashes Grow"/>
=== Coptic community in the diaspora === Memorial services were held in Coptic churches across Europe in memory of the victims of the bombing.<ref name="attack threats"/>
The [[Coptic Orthodox Church in the United Kingdom]] issued an official statement condemning the massacre, and expressing concern that incidents of violence and terror against Christians in Egypt were increasingly spiraling out of control.<ref name="Coptic Orthodox Church in UK">{{Cite news|title=Official Press Release of the Coptic Orthodox Church in the United Kingdom |url=http://coptsunited.com/Details.php?I=340&A=2801|accessdate=5 January 2011|date=4 January 2011}}</ref> The statement also criticized the fact that crimes against the Copts in Egypt were going unchecked and unresolved, and their perpetrators were not brought to justice.<ref name="Coptic Orthodox Church in UK"/>
In [[Montreal]], Canada, all five Coptic churches in the city decided to proceed under tightened security with the Eastern Christmas Eve mass on the eve of Eastern Christmas but decided not to hold any celebrations.<ref name="Montreal Gazette">{{Cite news|title=Coptic Orthodox Christmas to be low-key â Tight security: On alert after bombing in Egypt |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/life/Montreal+Coptic+Orthodox+Christmas/4054183/story.html|accessdate=5 January 2011|newspaper=Montreal Gazette|date=4 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Coptic churches in Canada on alert"/><ref name="thespec.com">[http://www.thespec.com/news/world/article/473776--harper-meets-with-coptic-christian-priests TheSpec â Harper meets with Coptic Christian priests]</ref> The celebrations were canceled in honor of the victims of the Alexandria massacre, and money that was to be spent on the celebrations was sent to the families of the victims in [[Alexandria]].<ref name="Coptic churches in Canada on alert"/> About 4,000 Coptics and some Muslim supporters marched on 19 January in central Sydney, calling on Prime Minister Julia Gillard and Foreign Minister Kevin Rudd to address the issue of persecution of Copts in Egypt.<ref name="9 News">{{Cite news|title=Australian Coptics protest persecution|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/8199070/australian-coptics-protest-persecution|last=Morello|first=Vincent|accessdate=22 January 2011|publisher=9 News|date=19 January 2011}}</ref>
=== Domestic === The Egyptian government issued a statement immediately following the bombing blaming "foreign elements" for the planning and execution of the bombing.<ref name="CNN"/><ref name="longwar"/>
President Hosni Mubarak promised in a televised address that terrorists would not destabilize Egypt or divide Christians and Muslims. He said the attack "carries evidence of the involvement of foreign fingers" and vowed to pursue the perpetrators.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="CNN"/><ref name="foreign hands">{{Cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12103248 | title= Egypt's president calls for unity after church bombing |publisher=BBC News | date= 1 January 2011 }}</ref> Many doubt that the perpetrators will be pursued, citing the Mubarak regime's preference for handling violence against the countryâs Christian minority through a reconciliation process between the perpetrators and the victims, rather than prosecution of the perpetrators.<ref name="CSM">{{Cite news|url= http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/the-monitors-view/2011/0104/Coptic-church-bombing-in-Egypt-Mubarak-must-prosecute|title=Coptic church bombing in Egypt: Mubarak must prosecute|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=4 January 2011 |page=2}}</ref>
The [[Alexandria Governorate|governor of Alexandria]], Adel Labib, accused [[Al Qaida]] of planning the bombing, without giving any further details.<ref name="ysaleh"/><ref>{{Cite news|url= http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/world/AlQaeda-linked-to-Egypt-blast.6677146.jp |title=Al-Qaeda linked to Egypt blast |first=Maggie |last=Michael |work=[[Scotland on Sunday]] |date=2 January 2011 |page=2}}</ref>
Many Egyptians expressed their disappointment regarding the government's claims that Al Qaida and foreign elements were behind the massacre,<ref name="Clashes Grow"/> seeing those claims as a way for the government to evade the issue of growing sectarian divisions in the country.<ref name="Clashes Grow"/>
In a message to [[Pope Shenouda III]], [[Patriarch Theodore II of Alexandria|Patriarch Theodore II]] of the [[Greek Orthodox Church of Alexandria]] strongly condemned the "brutal criminal attack" against a church "where prayers were being recited for the peace of Egypt, for the peace of those in power, and for the peace of the world."<ref name="Theodore">{{Cite news | url= http://freecopts.net/arabic/2009-10-15-12-56-17/2009-07-01-03-25-21/8218-2011-01-02-10-46-13 | title= Ø¨Ø·Ø±ÙØ±Ù Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ ÙØ¹Ø²Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙÙ Ø¶Ø­Ø§ÙØ§ ÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø§ÙÙØ¯ÙØ³ÙÙ | publisher=Free Copts | date= 2 January 2011 }}</ref> [[Patriarch Theodore II of Alexandria|Patriarch Theodore II]] also described the victims as "Martyrs of the Church".<ref name="Theodore"/>
Refaa al-Tahtawi, spokesman for Al-Azhar, Sunni Islam's main institution based in Cairo, appeared on television to denounce the attack, which he said targeted "Egyptian national unity". He also appealed to Christians and Muslims for calm.<ref name=jazeera />
The attack was also condemned by the [[Muslim Brotherhood]],<ref>[http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27729 Ikhwanweb :: The Muslim Brotherhood Official English Website]</ref> who also called upon Muslims to protect Christian churches.<ref>[http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27062 Ikhwanweb :: The Muslim Brotherhood Official English Website]</ref> On the eve of the Coptic Christmas on 6 January 2011, Egyptian Muslims showed up at churches during mass service offering to serve as a "human shield" against any possible further attacks.<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=Fox News|title=Egypt's Muslims Attend Coptic Christmas Mass, Serving as 'Human Shields'|url=http://nation.foxnews.com/coptic-christians/2011/01/15/egypts-muslims-attend-coptic-christmas-mass-serving-human-shields|date=15 January 2011|accessdate=21 January 2011}} </ref>
Both government and independent newspapers warned that civil war could break out in Egypt unless Muslims and Christians close ranks.<ref name="Asia One"/><ref name="The Australian"/> Newspapers also urged the Egyptian government to focus on the situation of the Copts, who often complain of discrimination.<ref name="Asia One"/><ref name="The Australian"/><ref name="AFP">{{Cite news | url= http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gM4ojQSkgen45AIWUkmRXYIsEFwA?docId=CNG.d0742101cf6091a508d93992474e7181.1e1 | title= Egypt media warn of civil war after bombing | publisher=Agence France Presse | date= 2 January 2011 | accessdate=2 January 2011}}</ref>
In a provocative act that deepened the feelings of the Coptic community of being increasingly victimized and marginalized, a high-ranking state security officer walked over to a row of demonstrators standing vigil in [[Cairo]] and slowly, methodically blew out the white candles they were holding to remember those who died in the attack.<ref name="Clashes Grow"/>
Interior minister Habib al-Adly said on 23 January that evidence proved that the Gaza-based [[Army of Islam (Gaza Strip)|Army of Islam]] planned and executed the attack. The group quickly denied responsibility, while also reportedly expressing support for the bombing.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt blames Gaza group for bombing|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112311414915283.html|accessdate=26 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=23 January 2011}}</ref>
In an interview that aired on Al-Fareen TV (Egypt) on 3 January 2011 (as translated by [[MEMRI]]), Former Egyptian Deputy Minister Abdallah Al-Ash'al stated that: <blockquote> "Today, many young people in Egypt are unhappy. They flee the country and prefer to die on the shores of the Mediterranean, because they have no job opportunities here...The Mossad has exploited this. The people who carried out this attack are Egyptians, but the Mossad exploited them...Are these nothing but theories? No. When [[Military Intelligence Directorate (Israel)|Israeli military intelligence chief]] [[Amos Yadlin]] submitted a report about the past four and a half years, he stated clearly that Israel was exploiting the peace treaty in order to infiltrate Egypt."<ref>[http://www.memritv.org/clip_transcript/en/2747.htm Egyptian Intellectuals Accuse the Israeli Mossad for the Alexandria Church Bombing], MEMRI TV, Clip No. 2747, 2â3 January 2011.</ref></blockquote>
=== International community === * In the days following the attack, [[Pope Shenouda III]] met with the ambassadors of the US, the UK and Bosnia and Herzegovina, who expressed the condolences of their respective countries to the Pope and to the [[Coptic Church]].<ref name="Ambassadors">{{Cite news|title=Ø³ÙÙØ¨Ù ØªÙØªÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØªÙØ¯Ù Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø¡ ÙØ§Ø´ÙØ·Ù ÙÙ Ø¶Ø­Ø§ÙØ§ ÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø§ÙÙØ¯ÙØ³ÙÙ |url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/january/4/consolation_washington.aspx|accessdate=10 January 2011|newspaper=Masrawy|date=4 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|Vatican City}} [[Pope Benedict XVI]] of the Roman Catholic Church denounced the attacks in his New Year address.<ref name="ysaleh"/> He also appealed for religious freedom and religious tolerance in the Middle East, and urged world leaders to defend Christians against discrimination, abuse and religious intolerance which are today striking Christians in particular.<ref name="VancouverSun">{{Cite news|title=Pope leads condemnation of Egypt church attack|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Pope+leads+condemnation+Egypt+church+attack/4048033/story.html|accessdate=2 January 2011|newspaper=Vancouver Sun|date=1 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] Dr. [[Rowan Williams]] condemned the bombing, declaring that "The New Year's Eve attack on Christians in Alexandria is yet another dreadful reminder of the pressure Christian minorities are under in the Middle East, echoing the atrocities we have seen in recent weeks", in reference to the [[2010 Baghdad church attack|attack on the church of Our Lady of Salvation]] in Iraq, carried out by the [[Islamic State of Iraq]].<ref name="Telegraph">{{Cite news|title=Car bomb in Egypt kills at least 17 outside Christian church|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8235037/Car-bomb-in-Egypt-kills-at-least-17-outside-Christian-church.html|accessdate=2 January 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=2 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagicon|United States}} U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] condemned the bombing, stating that: "The perpetrators of this attack were clearly targeting Christian worshipers, and have no respect for human life and dignity. They must be brought to justice for this barbaric and heinous act."<ref name="thehill.com">[http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/135579-obama-strongly-condemns-attacks-one-clearly-targeting-christian-worshippers Obama condemns attacks, one 'clearly targeting Christians' By Bridget Johnson â 1 January 2011 {{Nowrap|01:45 pm}} ET]</ref><ref>[http://democratifi.com/news/Obama-condemns-deadly-attacks-in-Egypt-Nigeria-1483197.html Obama condemns deadly attacks in Egypt, Nigeria. The Daily Caller]</ref> Obama also offered assistance to the Egyptian government in responding to the "terrible event."<ref name="thehill.com"/>
* {{flagicon|Canada}} Canadian Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] met with Coptic Christian leaders to condemn the Alexandria massacre and to confirm that Canada stands behind the right of the Copts to safely practice their faith.<ref name="thespec.com"/> He also declared that the international community must stay vigilant against such violence against Coptic Christians.<ref name="thespec.com"/>
* {{flagicon|Canada}} Canadian Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Lawrence Cannon]] issued a statement stating that "Canada condemns this latest vicious attack by extremists against Egyptâs Coptic community," and offering his sympathy with the families and friends of the victims.<ref name="Canada condemns">[http://coptsunited.com/Details.php?I=340&A=2800 Minister Cannon Condemns Attack on Coptic Church in Egypt â 04/01/11]</ref> The statement also called upon Egyptâs President Hosni Mubarak to close ranks and confront the terrorists who were behind this deplorable attack.<ref name="Canada condemns"/>
* {{flagicon|France}} French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] denounced the "blind and cowardly crime" against Christians in Egypt and expressed his "shock and great sadness". == Funeral == The funeral of the victims was held in the [[Monastery of Saint Mina]], about 30 km west of [[Alexandria]].<ref name="Elaph1">{{Cite news|title=Ø§ÙÙØ¯ÙØ¡ ÙØ¹ÙØ¯ ÙÙØ¥Ø³ÙÙØ¯Ø±ÙØ© ÙØ¥Ø¬Ø±Ø§Ø¡Ø§Øª Ø£Ù ÙÙÙØ© Ù Ø´Ø¯Ø¯Ø© Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø³|url=http://www.elaph.com/Web/news/2011/1/622047.html|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=Elaph|date=1 January 2011}} (in Arabic)</ref> Between 5,000 and 10,000 people attended the funeral, all of whom adamantly rejected the condolences of president [[Hosni Mubarak]], shouting "No! No! No!" as bishop Youanis attempted to thank [[Mubarak]] for his condolences and his statement regarding the bombing.<ref name="Asia One"/><ref name="The Australian"/><ref name="Elaph1"/>
In addition to Bishop Youanis, [[Pope Shenouda III]] delegated [[Metropolitan Archbishop|Metropolitan]] Bakhomios to preside over the funeral of those killed in Alexandria.<ref name="Ashraf Sadiq"/>
== Further threats == In Europe, Coptic churches have been threatened with further attacks.<ref name="attack threats">{{Cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12108677 | title= Coptic churches in Europe report attack threats |publisher=BBC News | date= 3 January 2011 }}</ref> Coptic bishops and priests in France and Germany filed complaints and called for governmental protection.<ref name="attack threats"/> In the UK, officials reported that threats were outlined against two Coptic churches in the country.<ref name="attack threats"/>
In Canada, Coptic churches were on high alert following threats by [[Al Qaida]] against Copts in Canada.<ref name="Coptic churches in Canada on alert">{{Cite news | url= http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2011/01/04/coptic-churches-canada.html | title= Coptic churches in Canada on alert | publisher=[[CBC News]] | date= 4 January 2011 }}</ref> All five Coptic churches in [[Montreal]] decided to proceed under tightened security with the Eastern Christmas Eve mass on the eve of Eastern Christmas.<ref name="Montreal Gazette"/><ref name="Coptic churches in Canada on alert"/><ref name="thespec.com"/> Following Coptic Christmas, Canadian prime minister [[Stephen Harper]] met with Coptic Christian leaders to condemn the Alexandria massacre and to confirm that Canada stands behind the right of the Copts to safely practice their faith.<ref name="thespec.com"/> He also declared that the international community must stay vigilant against such violence against Coptic Christians.<ref name="thespec.com"/>
The bombing also raised fears that [[jihadist]]s would increase violence against Christians worldwide.<ref name="Sarah A. Topol">{{Cite news | last= Topol | first= Sarah | url= http://www.newsweek.com/2011/01/03/in-egypt-a-widening-sectarian-crisis.html | title= In Egypt, a Widening Sectarian Crisis |work=Newsweek | date= 3 January 2011 }}</ref> Radical Islamic hostility to the Copts has been an ongoing problem. A "death list" featuring the names of 200 Copts, many of whom live in Canada and Austria, was recently published on an [[Al Qaida]]-affiliated website.<ref name="Coptic churches in Canada on alert"/><ref name="Death list">{{Cite news | last= Heiser | first= James | url= http://www.thenewamerican.com/index.php/world-mainmenu-26/north-america-mainmenu-36/5694-al-qaeda-targeting-christians-in-canada-austria | title= Al-Qaeda Targeting Christians in Canada, Austria | publisher=New American | date= 29 December 2010 }}</ref><ref name="the star">{{Cite news | last= Youssef | first= Marten | url= http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/910167--al-qaeda-affiliated-website-targets-arab-christians-in-canada?bn=1 | title= Al Qaeda-affiliated website targets Arab Christians in Canada | work=Toronto Star | date= 21 December 2010 }}</ref> The website called for the murder of all those whose names appear on the list, accusing them of defaming Islam and converting Muslims to Christianity.<ref name="Death list"/><ref name="the star"/>
